document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genus Cilliba von Heyden (Acari: Uropodina: Cillibidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. 2 ΨΨ, apparently syntypes , slide number 27 / 2 , no other data ( BSCZ ). Descriptions of male and deutonymph by
Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nicol ( 1964
, 1965 ).

Redescription. Female .
Moderately sclerotised, colour yellow.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 17–21.
Cilliba cassidoidea
, female. 17, dorsal idiosoma; 18, ventral idiosoma; 19, epistome; 20, chelicera; 21, hypostome (after Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nicol, 1969a).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ve n t r a l idiosoma (
Fig. 18
). Endopodal shields, sternal shield and anterior part of opisthosoma ornamented with small pits. Sternal setae st
1
located close to anterior edge of epigynium, st
2
–st
4
lateral to epigynium, st
5
behind articulation of genital shield. Epigynium tongue-shaped, covered entirely with numerous small oval pits. Opisthosoma smooth, except region behind epigynium covered with pits. Ventral setae (
v
1
–v
5
) simple, slightly widened,
v
1
= 2 / 3 length (
v
2
–v
5
);
v
4
located on small mounds. Adanal setae Ad
1
short, Ad
2
=
2 x
Ad
1
. Unpaired seta Pa = Ad
1
. Anal opening small, oval. Peritremes V-shaped. Tritosternum 6 -branched, with broad base, laciniae with finely serrated tips.

Gnathosoma
. Epistome narrow, laterally serrated, anterior processes finely spiculate (
Fig. 19
). Hypostomal setae h
1
long ( ca 116 µm), simple; h
2
short ( ca 32 µm), robust; h
3
short ( ca 42 µm), simple; h
4
short ( ca 50 µm), robust, laterally serrated (
Fig. 21
). Hypostomal surface covered with fine denticles of various sizes; denticles grouped in single row at the level of setae h
2
and distributed irregularly between setae h
3
–h
4
. Hypostomal groove finely serrated. Ventral setae pv
1
–pv
2
on palp trochanters robust and serrated; pv
1
ca 82 µm long, pv
2
ca 45 µm long. Chelicerae of average length, fixed digit with globular sensillus and small denticles on the internal surface, movable digit shorter than fixed digit, with single denticle on the internal surface (
Fig. 20
).
Dorsal idiosoma . Length ca 780 µm, width ca 715 µm. Ornamentation and chaetotaxy as for female.

Ve n t r a l idiosoma (
Fig. 22
). Sternal shield and anterior part of opisthosoma ornamented with circular pits of moderate size. Operculum oval, with a pair of long eugenital setae. Sternal setae simple, short. One pair of glands located near setae st
3
. Ornamentation and chaetotaxy of opisthosoma and peritremes as for female.

Gnathosoma
(
Fig. 23
). Epistome as for female. Hypostomal setae h
1
long, simple; h
2
very short, simple; h
3
short, simple; h
4
not present.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 22–27 .
Cilliba cassidoidea
. 22, male, ventral idiosoma; 23, male, hypostome; 24, male, leg II, posterolateral view; 25, deutonymph, dorsal idiosoma; 26, deutonymph, ventral idiosoma; 27, deutonymph, tritosternum (after Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nicol, 1969a).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ve n t r a l idiosoma (
Fig. 26
). Sternal shield amphora-shaped, with narrow base, entirely covered by oval pits, extending behind coxae IV. Sternal setae ( st
1
–st
5
) short, with widened bases. Two pairs of lyrifissures,
iv
1
near camerostome,
iv
2
behind setae st
5
. Ventral shield wide, smooth, ventral setae simple, with widened bases; all setae of equal length. One pair of lyrifissures (
iv
3
) located near setae
v
2
.
Anal shield triangular, with anal opening covered by a small valve and a pair of very short setae Ad
1
. Setae Ad
2
and Pa on shield surrounding the anus, Ad
2
= Pa . Peritreme long, with characteristic curve at level of coxae II, without poststigmatic extension, prestigmatic section reaching camerostome, stigmata at level of coxae III. Tritosternum 6 -branched, with broad base (
Fig. 27
).

Gnathosoma
. Epistome narrow and serrated, distally bifid. Structure and chaetotaxy of hypostome and palp trochanters similar to female except setae h
2
and h
3
serrated.

Ecology.
Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nicol ( 1969 a)
recorded this species from Spain , in the litter of oakchestnut forest (
Fig. 1
), and it has not been collected since.
